title: Russia at the 2014 Winter Olympics
text:
Russia competed at the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="Sochi">Sochi</a>, from 7 to 23 February 2014 as the host nation. As host, <a href="Russia">Russia</a> participated in all 15 sports, with a team consisting of 232 athletes. It is Russia's largest <a href="Winter%20Olympics">Winter Olympics</a> team to date.
In preparation for the Games <a href="Russian%20Olympic%20Committee">Russian Olympic Committee</a> naturalized a South Korean-born short-track speed-skater <a href="Ahn%20Hyun-soo">Ahn Hyun-soo</a> and an American-born snowboarder <a href="Vic%20Wild">Vic Wild</a>. They won a total of 5 golds and 1 bronze in Sochi.
Russia's medal count in 2014, 33 (before doping disqualifications), was its highest ever in the Winter Olympics, improving on the <a href="Russia%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics">1994 Games</a>, when the Russian team earned 23 medals overall, also beating the <a href="Soviet%20Union%20at%20the%20Olympics">Soviet Union</a>'s best medal count ever at the <a href="Soviet%20Union%20at%20the%201988%20Winter%20Olympics">Winter Olympics</a>.
Bobsledder <a href="Aleksandr%20Zubkov">Aleksandr Zubkov</a> was the flag bearer of the Russian team in the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics%20Parade%20of%20Nations">Parade of Nations</a> during the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics%20opening%20ceremony">opening ceremony</a>.
Following the Games, it was discovered that Russia's performance has been aided by a <a href="Doping%20in%20Russia">wider state-sponsored doping program</a>. On December 9, 2016 Canadian lawyer <a href="Richard%20McLaren%20%28academic%29">Richard McLaren</a> published the second part of his <a href="McLaren%20Report">independent report</a>. The investigation found that from 2011 to 2015, more than 1,000 Russian competitors in various sports (including summer, winter, and Paralympic sports) benefited from the cover-up.
At the end of 2017, IOC disqualified 43 Russian athletes and stripped Russia from 13 Sochi medals, but <a href="Court%20of%20Arbitration%20for%20Sport">Court of Arbitration for Sport</a> nullified 28 out of 43 disqualifications citing insufficient evidence and returned 9 out of 13 medals. In particular, on November 1, 2017 cross-country skiers <a href="Evgeniy%20Belov">Evgeniy Belov</a> and gold and silver medalist <a href="Alexander%20Legkov">Alexander Legkov</a> became the first athletes to be disqualified for doping violations after an investigation was completed. Four more were disqualified on November 9, 2017 when <a href="Maksim%20Vylegzhanin">Maksim Vylegzhanin</a>, <a href="Evgenia%20Shapovalova">Evgenia Shapovalova</a>, <a href="Alexei%20Petukhov">Alexei Petukhov</a>, and <a href="Julia%20Ivanova%20%28cross-country%20skier%29">Julia Ivanova</a> were sanctioned. The total was brought to ten when gold medalist <a href="Aleksandr%20Tretyakov%20%28skeleton%20racer%29">Aleksandr Tretyakov</a> and bronze medalist <a href="Elena%20Nikitina">Elena Nikitina</a> were banned along with <a href="Maria%20Orlova">Maria Orlova</a> and <a href="Olga%20Potylitsina">Olga Potylitsina</a> who were all skeleton racers. On November 24, 2017 the IOC imposed life bans on bobsledder <a href="Alexandr%20Zubkov">Alexandr Zubkov</a> and speed skater <a href="Olga%20Fatkulina">Olga Fatkulina</a> who won a combined of 3 medals (2 gold, 1 silver). All their results were disqualified, meaning that Russia lost its first place in the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics%20medal%20table">medal standings</a>. On November 27, 2017 IOC disqualified <a href="Olga%20Vilukhina">Olga Vilukhina</a>, <a href="Yana%20Romanova">Yana Romanova</a>, <a href="Sergey%20Chudinov">Sergey Chudinov</a>, <a href="Alexey%20Negodaylo">Alexey Negodaylo</a>, and <a href="Dmitry%20Trunenkov">Dmitry Trunenkov</a>, and stripped Vilyukhina and Romanova of their medals in biathlon. Three athletes who didn't win medals (<a href="Alexander%20Kasjanov">Alexander Kasjanov</a>, <a href="Ilvir%20Huzin">Ilvir Huzin</a>, <a href="Aleksei%20Pushkarev">Aleksei Pushkarev</a>) were sanctioned on November 29, 2017. Biathlete <a href="Olga%20Zaitseva">Olga Zaitseva</a> who won silver in a relay was disqualified on December 1, 2017. Two other athletes, <a href="Anastasia%20Dotsenko">Anastasia Dotsenko</a> and <a href="Yuliya%20Chekalyova">Yuliya Chekalyova</a>, were also banned. On December 12, 2017 six Russian ice hockey players were disqualified. On 18 December 2017 the IOC imposed a life ban on bobsledder <a href="Alexey%20Voyevoda">Alexey Voyevoda</a>. Eleven athletes were disqualified on December 22, 2017. Among them, silver medalists <a href="Albert%20Demchenko">Albert Demchenko</a> and <a href="Tatiana%20Ivanova">Tatiana Ivanova</a> who were stripped of their medals in luge. On 1 February 2018, nine medals were returned after an appeal to the <a href="Court%20of%20Arbitration%20for%20Sport">Court of Arbitration for Sport</a>. On 24 September 2020, one more medal was returned after an appeal to the <a href="Court%20of%20Arbitration%20for%20Sport">Court of Arbitration for Sport</a>.
Alpine skiing.
As a host nation, Russia has qualified a total quota of nine athletes in alpine skiing.
Biathlon.
Based on their performance at the <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202012">2012</a> and <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202013">2013 Biathlon World Championships</a> Russia qualified 6 men and 6 women. Irina Starykh originally qualified, but she withdrew from the team after testing positive for doping and was replaced by <a href="Olga%20Podchufarova">Olga Podchufarova</a>.
Cross-country skiing.
Russia qualified a maximum of 20 quotas (12 men and 8 women). For the first time since 1956, Russia (previously Soviet Union) failed to win a medal in women's cross-country skiing.

Team: <a href="Andrey%20Drozdov">Andrey Drozdov</a>, <a href="Aleksey%20Stukalskiy">Aleksey Stukalskiy</a>, <a href="Evgeniy%20Arkhipov">Evgeniy Arkhipov</a>, <a href="Petr%20Dron">Petr Dron</a>, <a href="Aleksandr%20Kozyrev">Aleksandr Kozyrev</a>

Figure skating.
As hosts, Russia was guaranteed a skater in each event.
Russia captured the inaugural gold medal in the team event. <a href="Yulia%20Lipnitskaya">Yulia Lipnitskaya</a>, at 15, became the youngest Russian Winter Olympic medalist, while <a href="Adelina%20Sotnikova">Adelina Sotnikova</a> won the first ever Russian ladies figure skating gold medal.
Freestyle skiing.
Russia qualified a maximum of 26 athletes (14 women and 12 men). Among them, <a href="Maria%20Komissarova">Maria Komissarova</a> had qualified to compete, but was seriously injured at the start of the Games during training, in a fall that left her paralysed below the waist.
Ice hockey.
As hosts, Russia automatically qualified a women's team. The men's team qualified as being one of the 9 highest ranked teams in the <a href="IIHF%20World%20Ranking">IIHF World Ranking</a> following the <a href="2012%20IIHF%20World%20Championship">2012 World Championships</a> (and would have qualified automatically as hosts if it didn’t qualify through rankings).
Women's tournament.
On December 12, 2017 six Russian players were disqualified for doping violations and all results of the team were annulled. <a href="Tatiana%20Burina">Tatiana Burina</a> and <a href="Anna%20Shukina">Anna Shukina</a> were also disqualified ten days later.
Luge.
Earning automatic places as a host nation, Russia has qualified a maximum of 10 spots (7 men, 3 women, and a relay team).
Short track speed skating.
As hosts, Russia have been given the maximum 5 men and 5 women to compete. On 10 February 2014, <a href="Viktor%20Ahn">Viktor Ahn</a> won the bronze medal in the 1500 m short track speedskating event. He won the first short track speedskating medal that Russia has earned while competing as Russia. On 15 February 2014, Ahn won the first Russian gold medal in short track at the 1000 m event, leading the first Russian 1-2 finish in short track, with <a href="Vladimir%20Grigorev">Vladimir Grigorev</a> winning silver. At 31 years and 191 days, Grigorev also became the oldest man to win a short track Olympic medal, with that silver. On 21 February 2014, he won the gold in the 5000 m relay, upping the oldest shorttrack male athlete record for both medals and gold medals.
Skeleton.
Russia qualified a maximum of 6 athletes (3 men and 3 women).
Ski jumping.
Russia has qualified a total of six athletes (five men and one woman)
Snowboarding.
Russia qualified a total of 15 athletes (11 men and 4 women). <a href="Vic%20Wild">Vic Wild</a> won two gold medals, which became the first ever gold medals for Russia in snowboarding. <a href="Alena%20Zavarzina">Alena Zavarzina</a> won a bronze medal in giant parallel slalom.
Speed skating.
Based on the results from the fall World Cups during the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20ISU%20Speed%20Skating%20World%20Cup">2013–14 ISU Speed Skating World Cup</a> season, Russia earned the following start quotas:
 Russia earned the max quotas (ten women and ten men) for speed skating, but only eight women competed. <a href="Viktoriya%20Filyushkina">Viktoriya Filyushkina</a> was a reserve for ladies' 3000 meter and <a href="Lada%20Zadonskaya">Lada Zadonskaya</a> was a reserve for ladies' 5000 meter. Both women qualified and were included in the Russian speed skating squad but didn't get to compete.
Doping scandal after Olympics.
In December 2014, German public broadcaster <a href="ARD%20%28broadcaster%29">ARD</a> aired a documentary which made wide-ranging allegations that Russia organized a state-run <a href="Doping%20in%20Russia">doping program</a> which supplied their athletes with <a href="performance-enhancing%20drugs">performance-enhancing drugs</a>. In November 2015, Russia's <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> team was provisionally suspended by the <a href="IAAF">IAAF</a>.
In May 2016, "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" published allegations by the former director of Russia's anti-doping laboratory, <a href="Grigory%20Rodchenkov">Grigory Rodchenkov</a>, that a conspiracy of corrupt anti-doping officials, <a href="Federal%20Security%20Service">FSB</a> intelligence agents, and compliant Russian athletes used banned substances to gain an unfair advantage during the Games. Rodchenkov stated that the FSB tampered with over 100 urine samples as part of a <a href="cover-up">cover-up</a>, and that at least fifteen of the Russian medals won at Sochi were the result of doping.
In December, 2016, following the release of the McLaren report on Russian doping at the Sochi Olympics, the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> announced the initiation of an investigation of 28 Russian athletes at the Sochi Olympic Games. Italian newspaper "<a href="La%20Gazzetta%20dello%20Sport">La Gazzetta dello Sport</a>" reported the names of 17 athletes, of whom 15 are among the 28 under investigation. The Russian team potentially could be stripped of up to 12 Olympic medals.
Three ladies artistic skaters were named as being under investigation. They are <a href="Adelina%20Sotnikova">Adelina Sotnikova</a>, the singles gold medalist, as well as pairs skaters <a href="Tatiana%20Volosozhar">Tatiana Volosozhar</a> and <a href="Ksenia%20Stolbova">Ksenia Stolbova</a>. Volosozhar and Stolbova won gold and silver medals, respectively, in pairs skating. Both also won gold medals in the team event, which also puts the other eight team medalists at risk of losing their golds.
Six skiers were suspended from competition on the basis of the McLaren report: <a href="Evgeniy%20Belov">Evgeniy Belov</a>, <a href="Alexander%20Legkov">Alexander Legkov</a>, <a href="Alexey%20Petukhov">Alexey Petukhov</a>, <a href="Maxim%20Vylegzhanin">Maxim Vylegzhanin</a>, <a href="Julia%20Ivanova%20%28cross-country%20skier%29">Yulia Ivanova</a>, and <a href="Yevgeniya%20Shapovalova">Yevgeniya Shapovalova</a>. Legkov won a gold medal, and Vylegzhanin won three silver medals.
The <a href="International%20Biathlon%20Union">International Biathlon Union</a> suspended two biathletes who were in the Sochi games: <a href="Olga%20Vilukhina">Olga Vilukhina</a> and <a href="Yana%20Romanova">Yana Romanova</a>, according to "<a href="La%20Gazzetta%20dello%20Sport">La Gazzetta dello Sport</a>". Vilukhina won silver in sprint, and both women were on a relay team that won the silver medal.
The <a href="International%20Bobsleigh%20and%20Skeleton%20Federation">International Bobsleigh and Skeleton Federation</a> suspended four skeleton sliders. They are among the six athletes on the skeleton team: <a href="Nikita%20Tregubov">Nikita Tregubov</a>, <a href="Aleksandr%20Tretyakov%20%28skeleton%20racer%29">Alexander Tretyakov</a>, <a href="Elena%20Nikitina">Elena Nikitina</a>, <a href="Maria%20Orlova">Maria Orlova</a>, and <a href="Olga%20Potylitsina">Olga Potylitsina</a>. Tretyakov won a gold medal, and Nikitina won a bronze.
